framework_intro.para:
Here is a framework to help you write a research proposal. There are spaces for you to add the content of your proposal.
Remember that you can double-click on any word to look it up in the dictionary.

commentary.para: The aim of the research proposal is to present your proposed research clearly and concisely so that institutions can assess whether they will be able to supervise your research, or—for undergraduates—to show that you have carefully planned the research project for your dissertation.

It is essential for you to show that you understand the field and the focus of your research. The core sections of the research proposal are (1) the literature review, (2) the aims or research questions, and (3) the data and methodology. You will also need to include (4) limitations and (5) contribution of the study. Each of these sections will shed light on how your research will make an original contribution to the field.
You can use this suggested outline to structure your research proposal.
The model text is from the field of Human Resources Management and shows the structure and aims of each section of a research proposal.
Note that the model does not show the preliminary title, table of contents or full bibliography.
The Introduction introduces the reader to the current state of knowledge in the field. It provides definitions, summarizes key research and links these to the purposes of the research.
This section demonstrates the writer's understanding of the current literature and displays the ability to critically evaluate the cited sources.
It shows that the proposed research will be an original contribution to the field.
The past tense is used to refer to cited research.
This section lists the aims of your study, using numbers.
It makes use of research verbs.
This section clarifies the proposed methodological approach and the data collection procedures.
It situates the proposed methodology within other research.
The future tense is used to refer to the proposed method.
This section highlight limitations, showing awareness of the challenges of the research. It proposes possible solutions.
Modal verbs are used to suggest limitations.
This section emphasizes the originality of the research and lists possible contributions of the research.
Modal verbs are used to hedge contributions.
Phrases with ‘this study’ or ‘this research’ identify and link different aspects of the discussion to the current study.
Phrases using words such as ‘lack’ show the research gap and point to the originality of this study.
Use of the personal pronoun ‘I’ to take ownership of the study.
The research proposal uses a combination of tenses and modal verbs.

checklist.point:
Preparing for your study
Start thinking about your research topic in plenty of time.
Define your research questions.

Literature
As you read the relevant literature, read critically, take notes and remember to record bibliographic data (title, author, date, publisher and page numbers) for every source you read.

Draft
Organize your notes into the necessary sections of the proposal and write your draft. Use the model to help you. Write concisely and avoid repetition.
Revise and edit your draft.
Provide a statement of how you will access resources and acquire skills, such as using statistical software, if asked to do so.
Language Bank: research verbs
Language Bank: reporting verbs
Grammar Focus: tenses
Grammar Focus: modal verbs
Have I planned my proposed research carefully and presented it clearly and concisely?
Have I shown that I understand and have evaluated the current literature?
Have I identified a gap in the research?
Are the aims of my study clear?
Have I explained my methodology clearly and situated it within other research?
Have I mentioned limitations and possible solutions?
Have I emphasized the contributions my study can make?
Have I included a full bibliography?
Have I used headings, subheadings and numbers to organize my writing?
Have I used tenses and modal verbs appropriately?
Have I checked vocabulary, grammar, spelling and punctuation?
